moves.1. d4: I started this game, so I have only myself to blame for being whacked in fine style. :-)
moves.1... f5: The Dutch Defence, quite common although 1...Nf6 and 1...d5 are both more usual.
moves.2. c4 Nf6 3. Nc3 e6 4. Nf3: This is all main line theory.
moves.4... Bb4 5. Bd2 b6 6. e3 Bb7 7. Bd3 O-O: The game has moved into a typical queen pawn setup.
moves.8. O-O d6 9. d5: I always like to advance pawns into my opponent's side of the board, but experience has taught me always to make sure my pawn formation is well backed-up first. As e4 is being attacked by an enemy pawn, I'm not so sure this is the case.
moves.9... Bxc3 10. Bxc3 exd5 11. cxd5: I should have seen that this loses a pawn.
moves.11... Ne4: A "zwischenzug" or in-between-move - these are always hard to spot, but this one isn't too bad at all.
moves.12. Bxe4 fxe4 13. Nd2 Bxd5 14. Nb3 Qg5: White's king is in a spot of bother. That pawn on e4 and semi-open f-file are recipes for disaster.
moves.15. g3: Blocking any attack lines down the g-file for the moment. The problem is that this weakens h3, which would be a great square for Black's queen, and if the e4-pawn were to disappear this lets Black's bishop stab right into White's kingside. A big weakness in White's position is that the f-pawn cannot move or he e-pawn will be captured, normally or by en passant if necessary.
moves.15... Nd7 16. h4: I am sure now that this was positionally an extremely weak move. In fact, after doing a move much like that in a similar position under the watchful eye of an IM, I was told I had "no understanding whatsoever of positional chess" and was a "rubbish positional player". I hope this was an exaggeration. But even I can see that this move leaves the king's position at the mercy of Black's queen.
moves.16... Qf5 17. Qe2 Qh3: Yep. I could see that one coming, as I had created a massive weak spot on h3. I didn't bother trying to defend it, though maybe I would have been OK after 17.Kg2 Be6 18.Rh1.
moves.18. Nd4 Ne5: Obviously, I don't want Black to put his knight on f3, forcing me to give up my queen. So instead I played the move that, I could see, would lead to my position being torn apart. Was that any better?
moves.19. f4 exf3 e.p. 20. Nxf3 Nxf3+ 21. Rxf3: This could really hurt. White is pretty well doomed, and Black is crushing him mercilessly. :-(
